commentBody: GRIDDIES 2025 VOTING ANNOUNCEMENT First-round voting on the 2025 Griddy Awards is now underway. You can find the ballot here: https://form.jotform.com/253465756808167 John Ezra, Marshall Walthew and I were pleased to see so many puzzles nominated. That does make the ballot rather lengthy ‚Äî I think there are about 100 puzzles across the four categories. The puzzle descriptions are not meant to simply remind you of the puzzle. We‚Äôve done our best to make sure that all the nominated puzzles are on the ballot. Our sincere apologies if you nominated a puzzle and it‚Äôs not on the ballot. If you wish to vote, be sure you‚Äôll have time to finish the ballot. As far as I can tell, there‚Äôs no way to save your choices if you start the ballot and don‚Äôt submit it. However, you‚Äôll get an email with your votes and may be able to add votes if you‚Äôre under five in any category.‚Ä®‚Ä®You will get a somewhat generic error message if you try to select more than five puzzles in any category. The message pops up as soon as you choose a sixth puzzle, so it‚Äôs easily fixed by deselecting one of your choices. It‚Äôs actually a pretty good way of keeping you focused on the best of the best. And if you want to be sure you‚Äôve selected five, try choosing one more. At the end of the relevant section of the ballot, it will say ‚ÄúThe maximum number of selections allowed is 5.‚Äù We hope you‚Äôll find the ballot user-friendly. If you have any trouble with it, comment here. One of us will see it. Thanks for voting!
Fun rebus concept. Well done.

So on the one hand they want to push everyone to do the puzzle online and on the other hand they make it impossible to figure out how to fill the squares online to have it count as completed. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
This was an amazing puzzle. Enjoyed it thoroughly. The fill was interesting and fresh. Also some of the theme entries are alliterative! Great experience.
This was one of those cases where I was proud to have picked up on the theme, and solved all theme crossing clues, before ever stumbling upon the revealer. A fun Sunday!

A fun puzzle that I knew how to solve but my phone didn't like how I formatted the rebus squares. I tried 2 ways that the article said were acceptable. Not the first time and I expect won't be the last.
Such a clever trick! One of my favorite puzzles from the last few months. üëè

SHEESH! Themes don‚Äôt get any tighter than this, between the grid art, 7 phi rebuses, and 7 symmetric phrases with a double I/O phrase at the beginning (and PHI as an entry itself). That‚Äôs all a feat ONTO itself, and I would have forgiven some clunky fill as a result, but it was all pretty smoothly done save for the occasional ETHENE or OBELI, nothing too untoward. I enjoyed both the fill and the solve quite a bit. The real kicker? I had an error I had to flyspeck at the end. I had POSH instead of PISH. And in the worlds of Mary Poppins: Oh, PISH-POSH! https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=8ozZiXIko9s

Love the grid design, the clever theme and the graphic. I agree that the stacking of MAZES and CR(I/O)SS PUZZLE is fun. 

Well done, Dylan.

P.S. I simply entered I/O for the eight rebus squares as I knew it represented PHI for the crossing entry. If that doesn‚Äôt work for you, trust me, you have an error elsewhere.

This one was so fun, I enjoyed it a lot! Thank you for making my Sunday better

This was a bit unfair as I had the ‚Äúphi‚Äù and an o in each of the correct spaces and my puzzle wouldn‚Äôt solve. Respectfully, this puzzle wasted my time and this was a little ‚Äútoo smart‚Äù for its own good. If my keyboard can‚Äôt make a symbol, then maybe don‚Äôt do puzzles like this. Thanks

"Abba" should be written as ABBA;
And "I atop an O" to describe the letter phi is awkward and misleading. "... that looks like an I and an O," or something of the like would be better.

Mostly good fill, average/good clueing. Nice rebus theme.

Well, it‚Äôs hard for me to be PHIlosoPHIcal about this, but I was halfway done before the giant PHI hit me between the eyes.
In trying to figure out a soPHIsticated method of getting the ping pong etc., the graPHIc obviousness eluded me. We all live for the teeny endorPHIn rush that comes with the delayed aha!

I‚Äôve been over and over and over my grid, and I can‚Äôt figure out why it won‚Äôt trigger as solved. I tried PHI, Œ¶, and IO for the gimmick squares. I checked every single other letter. It‚Äôs still ‚ÄúKeep trying.‚Äù ARGH.

Reading the early comments, I seem to be in the minority. But I didn't like this puzzle very much. I got the theme pretty easily (seen early with DINGDONGDITCH and SINGSONG_____). 

My problem is that the whole concept isn't very elegant. First because the answers can never look correct on the app. Second, because the repeated words won't look correct no matter what method or medium you use: DI/ONGDITCH, D[PHI]NGDITCH, or DŒ¶NGDITCH. None of those look anything like DINGDONGDITCH. Maybe the whole theme is a technical achievement with respect to cluing, but it just looks clunky and kinda ugly.
Easy-ish solve but quite a feat of construction. Nicely done.

Pretty good, fun puzzle to do.  Yet again Sunday turns out to be the most challenging puzzle of the week.  I guess it's the new policy?  This was way harder (and also a bit better) than the rest of the week for me.

Count me as someone who did not immediately recognize the "grid art".  I didn't know what a Phi looked like yesterday and won't remember it tomorrow.  The Greek trope of the title exists for a reason.

It just seemed like a janky attempt to illustrate something.  And it turns out it was.  :)

Personally I had the most trouble with the upper left, and that was only because I'd put in "omegi" instead of obeli and somehow managed to misspell angle!

I appreciated that, the dreaded STP Ape aside, this was pretty light on filler.  A good time.
WHO IS GOING TO KNOW TO USE A GREEK SYMBOL IN A CROSSWORD PUZZLE?! The rebus squares and kooky word games are bad enough. Why not just have all the answers be in Zapf Chancery or Dingbats?

It's often said in these comments that entering just the first letter of a rebus will be accepted.

I didn't find this puzzle difficult. I love rebuses. I pretty quickly/easily got this puzzle's trick, and simply entered a P in all 8 rebus squares (thinking the first letter of a rebus should be sufficient).

Luckily, I don't really care much about streaks and blue vs gold stars - if I did, I'd be mighty upset that my rebus entries weren't accepted. Because when I didn't get gold and checked puzzle, everything was perfect except the rebus squares.

Even if I had entered the rebuses correctly and got a gold star, I still would've felt 'meh' about this puzzle. Overall it just didn't spark any joy.
Rebus Philbin would have loved this one.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2026/01/10/sunday-january-10-2026/#ny

I liked the theme. ETHENE was the only answer that gave me serious trouble. Like Caitlin, I‚Äôd only ever heard of the compound referred to as ‚Äúethylene,‚Äù and I had ETHaNE in there until I finished a grueling fly-specking of the grid and noticed that SHaESH didn‚Äôt make sense. Now I think I need to take something for the headache; will paracetamol/acetaminophen or acetylsalicylic acid/aspirin do the trick?

I managed to get CONTES easier than I imagine many other solvers did through a somewhat circuitous route. In Japanese, a short comedy skit or sketch, such as might be performed on a variety show on TV, is called a ‚Äúkonto.‚Äù I still remember looking up the definition of the word in the Japanese equivalent of Merriam-Webster or Oxford when I first encountered it a couple of decades ago, and that the entry noted that it was borrowed from French, gave the Latin alphabet spelling, and stated that the original meaning en fran√ßais was a short tale that‚Äôs not necessarily comedic.
I was positive 114 across was Trumpy but it didn‚Äôt fit.

This was a quite a feat of construction! Brilliant theme nested in a complementary grid. I‚Äôm sorry some folks had technical issues (I entered PHI exclusively and it worked), but hopefully the genius of this theme isn‚Äôt lost in what‚Äôs sure to be a deluge of comments.

Thanks for a fun solve!

I love a good rebus, and this one was brilliantly constructed.  It was perfect for somebody from the (PHI)LADELPHIA area.  To start,  I admired the grid‚Äôs elegant look, but I did not recognize it as a depiction of phi.  I spotted the Greek letter trick at DEL(PHI), and expected a variety of other Greek letters to appear as rebuses throughout the puzzle.  That idea was quickly dashed and I began looking for phis.  I was a little perplexed as to why phi only worked in one direction, although I could at least discern the pattern, thus my ignorance did not hinder me.  Because I  had no idea what phi looked like, the reason for the I/O pairings eluded me until I finished.  When I became enlightened I went from thinking the rebus was wonky to thinking it was very clever.
I shall return later to the comments to œÜnd out who won the œÜght between ‚Äúit was horriœÜc‚Äù and ‚Äúit was magniœÜcent‚Äù‚Ä¶
Am I missing something? Why is sapphire spelled sapire? It didn‚Äôt accept the obvious, so I finally had it reveal the square. There were some other dubious answers as well. Not a fan.
Could have clued the FAY Wray movie as Kphing

Saw the enormous PHI before starting, and had the theme figured out in less than two minutes. Sadly, this made solving the rest of the puzzle a rather joyless experience for me.

Finished without help, and learned CONTES in the process.

Very clever theme, all in all.

An ingenious marvel of construction, if slightly œÜoiled by‚Äîin my case‚Äîglitchy rebuses. First I tried phi for all the theme entries, nothing doing. So I tried i/phi, nada again. Figured there was another typo somewhere, so I scoured the grid, zooming in section by section to flyspeck. Couldn‚Äôt find an error. Finally I changed all the rebuses to just i and got the happy music. Œ¶ew. For those of you who‚Äôve never heard Chopin‚Äôs Prelude Op. 28, No. 15, especially played by Horowitz, get thee to YouTube immediately: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=J_6APTb3RNQ&pp=0gcJCTIBo7VqN5tD
King Kong weeps he couldn‚Äôt find his way into this clever puzzle.
Mr Schiff, fantastic construction and a clever puzzle that I found an enjoyable distraction from the nerve-wracking news.  Thanks for your effort.

This was one of the hardest Sunday puzzles I've ever done. Almost gave up and went for an auto check but didn't want to lose my streak. I've been doing these for over 55 years now, and this one was a doozy! I eventually got it but oh man!

I had a bunch of answers that didn't fit.  I figured there was some kind of trick.  I got to the revealer and took out pencil and paper to make sure I had 8 phi's.  That also helped me phigure out how pingpong  etc., phit.   Then I saw the symbol in the grid.  So I didn't catch on as fast as some, but I got there.  Fun puzzle.  I liked the May 25, 2025 puzzle as well.

When I started playing crosswords about a year ago I really disliked rebus puzzles. But this is the kind of puzzle that‚Äôs helped me come to appreciate a rebus grid. Really well-constructed and well-clued. Bravo!

I call 'foul' on this one. Solving on my phone, 6 of the 8 rebuses were judged correct, but not the other two? I don't do the crosswords for streaks, so having to 'reveal' 2 squares to receive acknowledgement of completion doesn't really matter, but why??
My favorite puzzle of all time! Thank you!

ABLAUT time someone built a puzzle like this! If it‚Äôs been done before, nice REDUPLICATION of their efforts, but it‚Äôs the first time I‚Äôve seen it, and I loved it! Great work, Mr. Schiff! Looking forward to your next one!

It would have been much better if each time the solver entered PHI as a rebus, the PHI was immediately converted into the Greek phi, as happened at the very end, after solving the whole puzzle with PHIs.

Regarding THE GRIDDIES, Eric Hougland's message has full details, I'm just echoing what he's said (you can vote on as many as 5 in each category; it's easy to use, but see his post for more)... Here's the schedule moving forward: 1/11 - 1/16: Voting on First Round 1/18 - 1/25: Voting for Second (Final) Round 2/1: Announcement of winners & runners-up Here is the ballot: https://form.jotform.com/253465756808167 Anyone can participate; the ballot has descriptions of the puzzles, but all the puzzles are easily accessed in archives: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/archive Please note that if you scroll below the puzzle you'll find the Wordplay column if you wanted to refresh your memory of various puzzles.

After an over-average almost every day week a nice change of pace.
Being an across first solver I spotted (what I thought was) the I/O rebus early on and filled it in as such. I felt like I was zipping through until I started hitting the downs.
Much head scratching until I found some of the down rebuses(?) and knew something else was going on.
Then... AHA! If you know the feeling, you know.
In the end I was decently under average and enjoyed this puzzle more than any of the prior days of a challenging week for me.

Great job on construction of this crossword!.  Loved this one‚Äîhad fun figuring it out. Always great to get my gold star for completion, after a couple weeks of not correctly completing the puzzle.  I found it tricky in just the right way.

Ugh, I figured it out and pasted in a Œ¶ each time because it‚Äôs quicker than typing enter and PHI. Then it didn‚Äôt accept that so I had to go back and delete each one and tab thru to rebus it. Note to the web people: allow Œ¶ for the couple dozen people out there who think like me!
92 down, again with a mistake‚Ä¶a smart sea mammal is ‚Äúdolin‚Äù?!?!

Great fun. Not too hard, but seeing all the theme entries was a blast. Were my rebus entries supposed to turn into the appropriate symbol on my iPad upon successful completion?

THANK YOU!!!

 Even though I figured out the gimmick early on, I'm on the verge of breaking a 755-day streak, all because I can't figure out what combination of rebus babble will satisfy the Times' bot.
That was a fun one! Once I caught on I copied the Greek symbol Œ¶ and put that in each square and was pleased to see it worked.
44 minutes, pushed through despite some confusion, plugged in the last square and heard music. Which is good, because I sure didn‚Äôt want to have to go back and figure that one out.
Brilliant puzzle!

Beat my average by 27 minutes. 

Some of you are probably wondering how high my average must be that it can be beaten by 27 minutes. Your average may well be less than 27 minutes. I like to think that I get more time to enjoy a good puzzle.

This was a fun one. 

Here‚Äôs a question for the group. I usually solve the Sunday puzzle in 60 to 90 minutes. Recently I bought a printed Sunday Omnibus book of past NYT Sunday puzzles. They seem SO MUCH harder. I‚Äôm not so much bothered by clues featuring entertainers I don‚Äôt know, I expect that in an older puzzle. But the regular clues seem so obtuse. Has anyone else found this to be true?  All edited by Will Shortz.
I will again complain about the gimmicky stuff ruining the Sunday puzzle, the last place it should be.

Loved it. 

I had grumbled at "Ladybug's prey" only having three squares, because I was fairly certain they didn't eat Ant; but DEL[PHI] was definite enough that I was able to correct Ant to A[PHI]D. 

I'm sure there are complaints about a rebus (sigh) but I loved this.

Clever and creative, but a classic example of why I don't care for rebus puzzles. I'm diabetic and my eyes get tired at night and having to type in I/O and then have to go back through all eight rebus squares to enter PHI so I can get the solve means I'm using a lot of smaller letters that are harder to read for me. This one took me just over half an hour, which is within thirty seconds of my average, but it would have been quicker (and easier on the eyes) to not have to guess what variant the digital version needs to finish the puzzle.

Lot of fun‚Ä¶ I hung up on PER SE and PURR‚Ä¶ no clue what a rag doll does, and my mind didn‚Äôt parse PERSE.   Would have helped had I really, really known the real definition of PER SE!  Live and learn!

Got the phis though‚Ä¶ didn‚Äôt count the eighth until the music.  More learning!
I solved this puzzle and got the completion tune without entering any rebuses. All the rebus squares accepted simple i‚Äôs or o‚Äôs . I didn‚Äôt fully grasp the phi gimmick until I read the column.
This puzzle is TIPTOP for me!! I got my fastest Sunday yet with 22:02 and no hints. Loved all of it! Delphi gave it away early on, and I loved finding all the phis and the I/Os.
Doesn't make sense for some of the crosses and some of the downs...i.e. AMPHIBIA makes sense but the cross doesn't  - what exactly is a PPHINGPADDLE?

This was just elegant. I figured out what the trick must be about halfway through my solve, but I nervously awaited the moment I filled in the last square to see if my method had worked (entering I/O in a rebus square). When the happy screen popped up, I was elated. An excellent puzzle!
Another rebus puzzle to be tolerated at everyone‚Äôs expense.

makes me a teensy bit sad when clever or tough clueing is sacrificed for the gimmick.
once the rebus was detected, the level of difficulty for me fell to a tougher-than-usual tuesday.
another indirect bit of evidence, to me, that puzzles over the years are becoming objectively easier.

Sorry but I have another beef - why are the key clues always positioned deep into puzzles? Today's was 107 down? And asking for a friend - do most worders read the column before attempting to solve? Thanks.

For those of us that solve on a mobile device, can we get another color added (maybe green) for puzzles we solve without lookups or hints but missed the 2-day cutoff? I do all the puzzles in order, but it seems odd that not being able to keep up daily is treated the same as revealing clues when it comes to the color pattern (blue). I'm okay with giving up the gold star, but I'd like to differentiate between puzzles I completed on my own vs puzzles I needed help with.
Not my thing, but clever.

Easy puzzle with about 7 minutes added trying to figure out what EXACTLY to enter into the REBUS. The answer key is BS.

I wanted to love it and I got the theme right away, but it ultimately made me want to wrap myself in a grape leaf and hurl myself off a Spartan cliff.
This was a really excellent theme. A shifting rebus with a clever reveal clue AND the grid itself is designed to look like the Greek letter Phi? Fantastic. Phi-nominal, even.

Well done, Mr Schiff. This was elegantly done, from the double rebuses (let‚Äôs make rebii happen) to the grid construction.

Seeing RAFA at 1A reminded me of a ceremony honoring him at the most recent French Open, at which his name and an image of a trophy with the number 14 below it (the number of French Opens he won) were engraved in the clay beside the net at center court. Here's a link to a video of the event: - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LjDONWrr46I It's too long for most to watch (at 47 minutes), but if you go to the 30 minute mark, you'll see him greeted by three of his fiercest rivals during his long career. Quite a moving moment, and the mutual respect and camaraderie they all have for each other in spite of their intense rivalry is obvious.

Another annoying puzzle where you have to guess the arbitrary way to enter the answers when you know them and the theme.
On Thursday, would not accept rebus with the "inflated grades separated by a slash like "F/D'. 
However today entering Greek œÜ does not work, you have to use a rebus and enter "phi".
All so arbitrary. You can know all the answers and the 'trick' but still not get the particular ways to enter.

This felt like a great idea for a properly implemented Rebus feature. It doesn't appear that there's any interest at NYT Games in building one that doesn't make this puzzle feel incredibly clumsy and dissatisfying for me.

I'm sure others like it better, but to me, it's clever, but no fun at all.

Also, as I should have been saying in the months since I first saw it...there's a yawning chasm of difference between honing and sharpening. Please use a different clue.

This was the first Sunday puzzle I got a gold star on since mid-November. The theme was nice - DEL[PHI] gave half of it away very early into my solve. However, it took the revealer to make me understand how the other half of the trick worked. I never thought of the letter phi looking like an I crossed an O, but it does seem like it, does it not? The clueing was Tuesday-level, really, but I actually think that's great on Sunday. I never enjoy hard puzzles this time of the week - a huge and hard grid just takes too much effort, for me, and facing it feels like a chore rather than a fun, weekend activity. If I don't get a gold star upon entering the last letter, I just check the puzzle as I can't be arsed to flyspeck the immense grid. It felt great to not have to do that for once. For comparison, here is a screenshot of my "solve" of the tedious David Kwong Sunday on December 21st 2025: https://imgur.com/a/0esWg4w Also, I enjoyed how few proper names, abbreviations and crosswordese entries there were today - and what little of it there was I either knew or got from crosses without much effort. Perfection, for me. The constructor gets an A-plus from me. Can we please have more easy-ish, fun grids on Sundays, NYT? And now for something completely different - Lucek the Poodle resting after yesterday's walk in a snowy, freezing forest: https://imgur.com/a/9xFlEfx
Not hard to solve, but I never figured out the theme.
I read the column but have to admit I still don‚Äôt get how you get ding dong, tip top or hip hop.  I‚Äôll take the W with a shrug.
Absolutely loved this one. Breezy, clever, fun, perfect for a Sunday morning.

My 5 roommates plus I finished in under 40 minutes and had a blast! We loved the puzzle visual and the creativity with the words. Thank you Dylan! Keep up the good work and can't wait for your sixth puzzle <3

"This has to be DING DONG DITCH, which means that you have to use the Œ¶ symbol as an I ‚Äî but then, again, as an O."

Oh nonono. Come on.
Even after getting the theme early on, it took me way too long to realise that the grid design itself resembled a PHI. Very cool :)

Relating to Saturday‚Äôs crossing of Andrew MELLON and Mies van der ROHE, I just posted some remarks from Kameron Austin Collins on why he thinks that crossing is not a Natick. https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4d37pt?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share
Loved this one!

Apologies if this is an american spelling that I am unaware of, but in England the the gem before opal is spelled sapphire, not sapire! That threw me off for a long long while!! Otherwise a lovely puzzle!
This was an enjoyable puzzle. Very creative usage of phi. Took me 34 minutes, which is very apt for a lazy Sunday morning.

Liked it. Normally it irritates me to see non-latin glyphs used visually rather than phonetically (e.g. Œ£ for E, or Œª for a) but this use of Œ¶ was a nice exception. 

I hope some day a constructor braves the calumny of the NYT commentariat to produce a puzzle using ‰∏≠(Êñá).

Such a clever puzzle, loved it! Surprised there am was no animation at the end, but didn't see anything either on Android phone or iPad. Very clever anyway, more so than me; I have never heard of SOOST and spent a bit of time there trying to see what I'd done wrong.

Surprised to see how much love this one is getting in the comments.  Clever grid art with normal rotational symmetry as well as theme, but overall just way too easy to be that enjoyable for a Sunday.  Cluing was so straightforward and the very choppy fill required with the design just didn‚Äôt make for that much fun for me.
An absolute delight of a puzzle! Has to be one of my favourite Sunday puzzles ever <3
Instructions did not work for me. Said you could enter PHII/O but only when I changed them all to PHI did it solve. Too gimmicky for me.

The original Sophists sound like someone to avoid‚Ä¶. Really thought Pish was meant to be a theme answer as pish posh, and missed for a long while the Ace /
As a set error I had by having ‚Äúin a set‚Äù. Was
good going up to about 3/4s in though. I don‚Äôt
Know, the grid size seems to lead to being a bit lost by the end of a rebus is involved- but glad to do my first full week.

I like that the puzzle started even before filling in the first letter ‚Äì wondering what picture those black squares were making.

I‚Äôm uber-impressed that those theme answers in which the phi represents I/O, are symmetrical.  

I‚Äôm also impressed with how the two islands in the middle (the phi halves) are filled and clued, showcasing the art of puzzle-making.  If it‚Äôs too hard you‚Äôre stuck forever; if too easy, it‚Äôs boring mindless fill-in.  I think they nailed it.

Finally, I‚Äôm impressed with the tightness of the I/O phrases (such as FLIP FLOP and SING SONG). There are not too many in our language aside from those in the box today.

The solve incorporated the fun of finding the Œ¶‚Äôs with the delight of seeing the two answers each engendered.  All on top of the normal riddle-cracking pleasure of filling in the boxes.

I came into the box neutral and left it feeling the buzz of a rich experience.  Bravo and thank you, Dylan!

Sunday mornings with a crossword, a snoring hound, and a delicious cup of coffee are absolutely precious to me. 

When a constructor presents a puzzle that is as enjoyable to solve as this one, I feel compelled to thank them for the icing on the cake.

SOME advice, culled from the great @David Connell--

WHEN faced with puzzle with a rebus, or similar gimmick, in which you get the gimmick, but are not sure what format the puzzle will accept to ensure your Gold Star, erase one square of which you're absolutely sure--1A/1D is always a good one--and fill it in at the very end. If you hear the Happy Music, fine; if not--erase it, go back, edit your Gimmick squares, and try again; if still not--go read Wordplay. 

I used this method a few days ago, on the "grade inflation" puzzle, and I used it today.

@FWIW

The general consensus is that the puzzles have gotten much easier over the years.

@FWIW

The puzzle used to be just one part of a printed paper that in New York attracted the most sophisticated readers. The Daily News and New York Post catered to everyone else. 

After the paper was online for a while and began to get a more international audience, people from everywhere began solving daily. 

Eventually, there was a class of people who had a subscription mainly for the puzzle, and they didn‚Äôt necessarily match the erudition of the original group. But since they were greater in number, they had a greater voice in the direction the puzzle went. And to exacerbate matters, the NYT decided to create a games-only subscription, so you no longer had to have the knowledge that comes from being a NYT reader. 

The NYT puzzle was never meant to be for everyone. But then everyone wanted to do it. And do it successfully, for that matter. In fact, the Wordplay columnists started telling people that everyone could solve the NYT puzzle. 

The old time crowd has noticed that the puzzle has become easier. Or maybe we‚Äôre getting much better.

@Steve L
We may be getting better, but the puzzle has definitely become easier in most cases.
